questions.question: Question 1: Urine sample of a patient has been collected for analysis. How soon should it be analyzed?
questions.explanation:
Urine samples should be analyzed within 2-4 hours after collection to avoid cell lysis and 
precipitation of solutes. If urine analysis is not possible in the given time, then the sample can be 
stored at 4-8 oC for a maximum of 12 hours. Urine samples can be collected using the following techniques: • Midstream sample during spontaneous voiding • Fresh specimen from an indwelling catheter • Suprapubic needle aspiration of the bladder, especially in infants

questions.question: Question 2: All of the following determine the color of urine except:
questions.explanation:
The solubility of solutes is not a determining factor of the color of urine. Determinants of the color 
of urine are: • Chemical content • Concentration • pH (Normal pH is 4.5-8) The normal color of urine is pale straw due to the presence of urochrome.

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following drugs can cause green-colored urine in a patient?
questions.explanation: Green urine can be caused by triamterene, a potassium-sparing diuretic.

questions.question: Question 4: What value of urine specific gravity is called isosthenuria?
questions.explanation:
Isosthenuria is defined as a urine specific gravity of 1.010, which is similar to that of plasma. The 
normal specific gravity of urine is around 1.020 to 1.030. Specific gravity and osmolality are measures of the concentration or relative density of urine. • Specific gravity: The weight of a solution relative to that of equal amounts of water. It is 
measured by refractometry or using reagent strips. • Osmolality: The gold standard for relative density. It is defined as the number of osmoles of 
solute per kilogram of solvent. It is measured directly with an osmometer. Isosthenuria means that the kidney is neither concentrating nor diluting the urine. This is seen 
in chronic renal failure (CRF) and acute tubular necrosis (ATN). Abnormality 
Causes Isosthenuria 
CRF, ATN 690 
Sold by @itachibot Abnormality 
Causes Diabetes insipidus Hyposthenuria (low specific g 
ravity) Hypersthenuria (high specific SIADH, Severe dehydrati 
on gravity)

questions.question:
Question 5: A patient is being evaluated for the following appearance of his urine. A urine dipstick test is 
performed and the result is negative. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given image shows reddish discoloration of the urine sample. A negative urine dipstick 
indicates absence of RBCs and is suggestive of porphyria. A urine dipstick test is the first step to be done in a patient with high coloured urine to help 
identify true hematuria. A positive dipstick test identifies heme that is present in red blood cells, 
haemoglobin or myoglobin. A negative dipstick test implies that the reddish discolouration is due 
to pigments from certain food items (beetroot), drugs or porphyrias.

questions.question:
Question 6: Which of the following patients are considered to have significant hematuria based on their 
urine analysis findings?
questions.explanation:
Hematuria is defined as the presence of 2-5 RBCs / high-powered field (HPF). It is considered 
significant or persistent in the presence of one of the following: • RBCs > 3 / HPF on 3 or more occasions • RBCs > 100 / HPF on 1 occasion • Gross hematuria 691 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 7: 686 
Sold by @itachibot A patient with hematuria, generalized edema, and abdominal distension is suspected to have 
a glomerular pathology. Which of the following is likely to be seen in the urine?
questions.explanation:
Acanthocytes are a subtype of dysmorphic red blood cells with protruding blebs that are seen in 
glomerular disease. The 40-5-1 rule can be used to identify glomerular diseases based on urinalysis: • Dysmorphic RBCs - 40% (can range from 10-80%) • Acanthocytes - 5% (can range from 2-5%) • Even a single RBC cast Hematuria can be either due to systemic or renal causes. Renal causes can be further subdivided 
into glomerular and non-glomerular causes as given below: Glomerular 
Non-glomerular Dysmorphic RBCs seen (abno 
rmal shape and size) Isomorphic RBCs seen (norm 
al shape and size) RBC casts may be present 
RBC casts always absent MCV is reduced (<•2 fl) 
MCV is normal Protein excretion > 1g /day 
Protein excretion < 1g /day The cause is usually medical 
The cause is usually surgical

questions.question:
Question 8: An 18-year-old boy presents to the clinic with a history of malaise. He was diagnosed with 
mild sensorineural hearing loss nearly 10 years ago. He also has a history of recurrent 
hematuria. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: This clinical scenario is suggestive of Alport syndrome. The clinical features include: • Recurrent hematuria and nephritic syndrome • Sensorineural hearing loss • Anterior lenticonus Other causes of recurrent hematuria include: • Alport syndrome • IgA nephropathy • Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) • Papillary necrosis • Renal cell carcinoma

questions.question: Question 9: Which of the following is true about proteinuria?

options.a: Proteinuria is always due to glomerular pathology
options.b: Albuminuria upto 150 mg/day is considered normal
options.d: Proteins are reabsorbed in the DCT

questions.explanation:
Nephrotic-range or heavy proteinuria refers to excretion of > 3.5 g/day or > 1000 mg/m2/day 
in children. 692 
Sold by @itachibot Normally, the following mechanisms prevent proteinuria: • The glomerular basement membrane acts as a barrier to prevent the loss of negatively charged 
and large proteins. • Reabsorption of small proteins in the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT). The various types of proteinuria are: • Glomerular - increased filtration of proteins due to disruption of basement membrane • Tubular - damage to tubules prevents protein reabsorption in the PCT • Overflow - excess production of low molecular weight proteins such as light chains • Postrenal - infections or stones can lead to secretion of IgA and IgG by the urinary tract Type of Proteinuria

questions.question: Question 10: All of the following findings in a patient are suggestive of non-glomerular proteinuria except:
questions.explanation:
Non-glomerular proteinuria is characterized by the presence of N-acetyl glucosaminidase (NAG). This form of proteinuria occurs as a result of tubular injury. N-acetyl glucosaminidase (NAG) is a 
lysosomal enzyme present in the proximal tubular cells and is released into the urine following 
any injury to the tubules. ˜ow-molecular-weight proteins such as 2-microglobulin are normally reabsorbed in the PCT. 
When there is tubular injury, the proportion of these proteins in urine increases. This lowers the 
albumin: 2-microglobulin ratio in urine. In glomerular proteinuria, there is increased filtration of macromolecules like albumin across the 
glomerular capillary wall. NAG is absent as there is no tubular injury. Glomerular proteinuria 
Non-glomerular proteinuria ˜ow molecular weight (2-mi 
croglobulin) Type of protein excreted

questions.question:
Question 11: A patient presents with recurrent kidney stones. The microscopic examination of urine is 
shown below. What is the type of stone seen in this patient?
questions.explanation:
The image shows a hexagonal crystal, suggesting cystine stones. These stones are a recurrent 
feature in patients with cystinuria. Crystals in urine are usually associated with kidney stones. Crystals form in the urine depends 
upon a variety of factors including: • The degree of concentration of constituent molecules • The urine pH • The presence of inhibitors of crystallization Calcium oxalate and uric acid crystals can sometimes be found in normal urine that has been left 
to stand, due to crystal formation ex vivo.

questions.question: Question 12: Which of the following is incorrect about casts in urine?

options.a: Width of cast depends on the size of tubule in which it is formed
options.b: Casts in urine are specific to kidneys
options.c: Site of formation is proximal convoluted tubule
options.d: Casts are made up of uromodulin

questions.explanation:
The sites of formation of casts are the collecting ducts and DCTs (distal convoluted tubules). Casts are cylindrical structures formed by the aggregation of Tamm-Horsfall mucoprotein or 
uromodulin. This protein is secreted in the thick ascending loop of Henle. They assume the shape 
and size of the lumen in which they are formed. Several factors favour cast formation, such as 
urine stasis, low pH and high concentration. Casts are the only elements in urine sediments that 
are specifically of renal origin.

questions.question:
Question 13: A patient with cryptococcal meningitis was started on amphotericin B. Two days later, he is 
found to have decreased urine output. Urinalysis reveals granular casts. What could be the 
possible diagnosis? 688 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Muddy-brown granular casts are seen in acute tubular necrosis, a type of intrinsic renal failure. 
ATN can occur secondary to nephrotoxicity or hypovolemia.

questions.question: Question 14: Which of the following casts are associated with a poor prognosis?
questions.explanation:
Broad casts are associated with a poor prognosis. They refer to wider waxy casts that are seen in advanced chronic kidney disease. It implies 
dilation of the tubules. 694 
Sold by @itachibot Chronic Kidney Disease
